<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:date_created" content="September 30, 2025 at 3:00 AM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="2946"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Actor Groups"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Lior Rochberger"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="China,CL-STA-0043,Phantom Taurus,TGR-STA-0043"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Phantom Taurus: A New Chinese Nexus APT and the Discovery of the NET-STAR Malware Suite","name":"Phantom Taurus: A New Chinese Nexus APT and the Discovery of the NET-STAR Malware Suite","description":"Phantom Taurus is a previously undocumented Chinese threat group. Explore how this group's distinctive toolset lead to uncovering their existence.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phantom-taurus\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phantom-taurus\/","datePublished":"September 30, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nPhantom Taurus is a previously undocumented nation-state actor whose espionage operations align with People\u2019s Republic of China (PRC) state interests. Over the past two and a half years, Unit 42 researchers have observed Phantom Taurus targeting government and telecommunications organizations across Africa, the Middle East, and Asia.\r\n\r\nOur observations show that Phantom Taurus\u2019 main focus areas include ministries of foreign affairs, embassies, geopolitical events and military operations. The group\u2019s primary objective is espionage. Its attacks demonstrate stealth, persistence and an ability to quickly adapt their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs).\r\n\r\nWhat sets Phantom Taurus apart from other actors in the Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) nexus is its distinctive set of TTPs. These enable the group to conduct highly covert operations and maintain long-term access to critical targets. This article sheds more light on the threat actor\u2019s recently observed TTPs and reveals a previously undocumented custom tool in Phantom Taurus\u2019 arsenal called NET-STAR.\r\n\r\nWe published our first article about this activity cluster (originally tracked as CL-STA-0043) in June 2023. In May 2024, we promoted the classification of this cluster to a temporary group, which we designated TGR-STA-0043 and nicknamed Operation Diplomatic Specter. Our ongoing investigations into this group deepened our understanding of the threat actor\u2019s operations and enabled us to determine its connection to the Chinese nexus. This rare level of insight reflects the depth and duration of our investigation.\r\n\r\nAfter sustained observation and intelligence collection over the past year, we have accumulated sufficient evidence to classify the temporary group as a new threat actor. Our attribution and cluster maturation process is based on Unit 42\u2019s attribution framework. Figure 1 shows the process of promoting Phantom Taurus from a cluster of activity to a formally named threat actor.\r\n\r\nFigure 1 shows the process of promoting Phantom Taurus from a cluster of activity to a formally named threat actor.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_159755\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 1. The maturation process of Phantom Taurus.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nThreat Actor Groups, TGR-STA-0043, CL-STA-0043\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPhantom Taurus: The Evolution of a Threat Actor\r\nPhantom Taurus is a Chinese APT group that conducts long-term intelligence collection operations against high-value targets to obtain sensitive, non-public information.\r\n\r\nThe group primarily targets government entities and government service providers across the Middle East, Africa and Asia. The targeting patterns align consistently with the People's Republic of China (PRC) economic and geopolitical interests. We observed that the group takes an interest in diplomatic communications, defense-related intelligence and the operations of critical governmental ministries. The timing and scope of the group\u2019s operations frequently coincide with major global events and regional security affairs.\r\n\r\nOur technical analysis reveals that the group employs a unique set of custom-developed tools and implements techniques that are rarely observed in the threat landscape. The list of TTPs is provided in Appendix A.\r\n\r\nThis group's distinctive modus operandi, combined with its advanced operational practices, sets Phantom Taurus apart from other Chinese APT groups. The designation of this group as a distinct Chinese APT is supported by multiple attribution factors, as illustrated in the Diamond Model of attribution [PDF] shown in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158627\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Diamond Model representation of Phantom Taurus.[\/caption]\r\nDiamond Model Attribution Breakdown\r\nWe established the attribution of Phantom Taurus through a comprehensive analysis of the following Diamond Model elements:\r\n\r\n \tInfrastructure: Phantom Taurus uses a shared Chinese APT operational infrastructure that has been exclusively used by Chinese threat actors, including Iron Taurus (aka APT27), Starchy Taurus (aka Winnti) and Stately Taurus (aka Mustang Panda). However, the specific infrastructure components used by Phantom Taurus have not been observed in operations by other threat actors, indicating operational compartmentalization within this shared ecosystem.\r\n \tVictimology: The group consistently targets high-value organizations that have access to sensitive non-public information. Over the past several years, we have observed Phantom Taurus targeting government and telecommunications sector organizations, particularly those that provide services and infrastructure. This group focuses its operations on the Middle East, Africa and Asia, reflecting intelligence collection priorities that align with Chinese strategic interests.\r\n \tCapabilities: Phantom Taurus employs a set of TTPs that differentiate it from other threat actors. Several of these techniques have not been observed in operations by other groups, while others are sufficiently rare that only a handful of actors have been observed using similar methods. In addition to common tools such as China Chopper, the Potato suite and Impacket, the group uses customized tools, including the Specter malware family, Ntospy and the NET-STAR malware suite described later in this article.\r\n\r\nBy using the Diamond Model of attribution with the three nodes shown in Figure 2, we mapped the group\u2019s similarities and overlaps with other threat actors. As we tracked the activity for an extended period, it became clear that the activities that we observed were carried out by a new threat actor.\r\nCharting the Course From Email to Databases: Phantom Taurus\u2019 New Data Collection Methods\r\nOur continuous monitoring of Phantom Taurus activities has revealed a tactical evolution that we first observed in early 2025. Since 2023, Phantom Taurus has focused on stealing sensitive and specific emails of interest from email servers, as we described in a previous article. However, our telemetry indicates a shift from this email-centric methodology to the direct targeting of databases.\r\n\r\nWe observed Phantom Taurus using a script named mssq.bat to connect to and collect data from a targeted database.\r\n\r\nThe mssq.bat script operates in the following manner:\r\n\r\n \tConnects to an SQL Server database with a given server name, a user ID named sa (system administrator) and a password that the attackers previously obtained\r\n \tReads the SQL query provided in the command-line arguments by the group\u2019s operators. This allows dynamic searching for tables and specific keywords\r\n \tExecutes the provided query and returns the results that match the user\u2019s search\r\n \tExports results to a CSV file\r\n \tCloses the database connection\r\n\r\nThe threat actor leveraged Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute the mssq.bat script on the remote SQL Server. Figure 3 shows that the command contains both the embedded script and the execution instructions.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158638\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. Execution of mssq.bat as shown in Cortex XDR.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe threat actor used this method to search for documents of interest and information related to specific countries such as Afghanistan and Pakistan.\r\nThe New NET-STAR Malware Suite\r\nIn addition to Phantom Taurus\u2019 shift to collecting data from databases, we observed the group using a new and undocumented malware suite in its recent operations. This new tool is a .NET malware suite designed to target Internet Information Services (IIS) web servers. We named the suite NET-STAR, based on the use of the string in the malware\u2019s program database (PDB) paths:\r\n\r\n \tC:\\Users\\Administrator\\Desktop\\tmp\\NETstarshard\\ServerCore\\obj\\Release\\ServerCore.pdb\r\n \tC:\\Users\\admin\\Desktop\\starshard\\NETstarshard\\ExecuteAssembly\\obj\\Debug\\ExecuteAssembly.pdb\r\n\r\nThe STAR string also appears as a delimiter in Base64-encoded data. The NET-STAR malware suite demonstrates Phantom Taurus\u2019 advanced evasion techniques and a deep understanding of .NET architecture, representing a significant threat to internet-facing servers. The suite consists of three distinct web-based backdoors, each serving a specific role in the attack chain while maintaining persistence within the target\u2019s IIS environment:\r\n\r\n \tIIServerCore: A fileless modular backdoor that supports in-memory execution of command-line arguments, arbitrary commands and payloads\r\n \tAssemblyExecuter V1: Loads and executes additional .NET payloads in memory\r\n \tAssemblyExecuter V2: An enhanced version of AssemblyExecuter V1 that is also equipped with Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) and Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) bypass capabilities\r\n\r\nIIServerCore: A Modular Fileless IIS Backdoor\r\nIIServerCore is the main web-based backdoor component in the NET-STAR malware suite. After being loaded by the web shell loader component, the backdoor operates entirely in memory within the w3wp.exe IIS worker process.\r\n\r\nThe IIServerCore backdoor has a unique modular, fileless execution flow that allows it to:\r\n\r\n \tReceive additional payloads and arguments\r\n \tExecute them in memory\r\n \tSend the results in an encrypted command and control (C2) communication channel\r\n\r\nFigure 4 shows the execution flow.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158649\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 4. IIServerCore execution flow.[\/caption]\r\nIIServerCore Under the Hood: From Web Shell Loader to Fileless Malware\r\nThe initial component of IIServerCore is an ASPX web shell named OutlookEN.aspx. This web shell contains an embedded Base64-compressed binary, the IIServerCore backdoor. When the web shell executes, it loads the backdoor into the memory of the w3wp.exe process and invokes the Run method, which is the main function of IIServerCore. Figure 5 shows the web shell.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158660\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1073\"] Figure 5. Web shell content of OutlookEN.aspx.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn an attempt to evade detection efforts, the threat actor timestomped the ASPX file to match the timestamp of another old ASPX file found on the operating system. The threat actor timestomped not only the web shell, but also the backdoors in the NET-STAR malware suite. The actor changed the compilation time to a random future date to hide the malware\u2019s real compilation timestamp.\r\n\r\nIIServerCore also supports a command called changeLastModified. This suggests that the malware has active timestomping capabilities, designed to confuse security analysts and digital forensics tools.\r\nBreaking Down IIServerCore Method by Method\r\nThe IIServerCore backdoor consists of a class called ServerRun and 11 methods. This includes a main method named Run as well as several others that provide additional capabilities. The methods and their descriptions are listed in Appendix B.\r\n\r\nThe main method, Run, receives the incoming communication and handles all malware operations. This method processes two types of requests:\r\n\r\n \tInitial handshake requests to establish a session with the C2 server\r\n \tSubsequent command execution requests to load and execute .NET assemblies dynamically\r\n\r\nFigure 6 shows the Run method.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158671\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"791\"] Figure 6. Screenshot of IIServerCore main method Run.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe Run method manages the session state using cookies. This behavior allows the method to track and maintain information about a user\u2019s session across multiple web requests. It decrypts incoming commands and payloads, loads .NET code from Base64-encoded assemblies and supports data encryption.\r\n\r\nThe backdoor supports various built-in commands that provide a wide range of functionalities, including:\r\n\r\n \tFile system operations\r\n \tDatabase access, including running SQL commands\r\n \tArbitrary code execution\r\n \tWeb shell management to deploy and manage multiple web shells\r\n \tAntivirus evasion: AMSI bypass functionality\r\n \tEncrypted C2 communication, where all communications are AES encrypted\r\n \tMemory-only execution: payloads are loaded directly into memory\r\n\r\nThe full list of commands is provided in Appendix C.\r\nTwo New Variants of .NET Malware Loaders\r\nThe second component in the NET-STAR suite is another .NET IIS malware that we named AssemblyExecuter. During our investigation, we observed two versions of AssemblyExecuter:\r\n\r\n \tAn older version (v1) that we believe the threat actors initially used around 2024\r\n \tA newer version (v2) that we believe they used in 2025\r\n\r\nAssemblyExecuter V1\r\nThe first AssemblyExecuter version is a .NET assembly designed for a single, specific purpose of executing other .NET assemblies directly in memory without writing them to disk.\r\n\r\nThis component enables threat actors to dynamically load and execute additional functionality after a compromise. The backdoor accepts assembly bytecode as input parameters, loads it using the .NET\u00a0Assembly.Load() method and invokes the assembly\u2019s entry point along with specified command-line arguments.\r\n\r\nThe component\u2019s seemingly benign code structure results in minimal flagging by antivirus engines on VirusTotal, at the time of writing this article. This demonstrates a technique that threat actors can use to create tools that avoid overt code, which detection systems might interpret as malicious.\r\nAssemblyExecuter V2\r\nThe second AssemblyExecuter version maintains the same core purpose as its predecessor, executing arbitrary .NET assemblies directly in memory. This version has enhanced evasion capabilities to operate in more heavily monitored environments.\r\n\r\nWhile the fundamental assembly loading and execution logic remain unchanged, AssemblyExecuter v2 includes dedicated methods for bypassing two critical Windows security mechanisms, AMSI and ETW. The malware dynamically determines which bypass techniques to apply based on input parameters, allowing attackers to selectively disable security controls, depending on the target environment\u2019s configuration.\r\n\r\nFigure 7 displays the input parameters that the attackers used to achieve bypass.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158682\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"768\"] Figure 7. Security bypass code inside AssemblyExecuter V2.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nThis article details the maturation of activity cluster CL-STA-0043 to a formally designated threat actor, Phantom Taurus. We also provide a detailed technical analysis of NET-STAR, a previously undiscovered malware suite that represents a significant evolution in this actor's operational capabilities.\r\n\r\nThe extensive evidence that we gathered provides crucial insights into adversary persistence, adaptability, evolution process and strategic intent that short-term analysis cannot always capture.\r\n\r\nThe formal designation of Phantom Taurus demonstrates the value of sustained threat actor tracking. Our multi-year investigation exemplifies how long-term monitoring enables a comprehensive understanding of threat actor evolution and operational capabilities.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.\r\n \tAdvanced Threat Prevention has an inbuilt machine learning-based detection that can detect exploits in real time.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM.\r\n\r\n \tThe XDR agent is designed to protect against the initial NET-STAR malware loader, preventing the execution of the attack chain outlined in this article.\r\n \tFigure 8 shows that the execution of the loader component was detected and prevented by the web shell protection module.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_158693\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"970\"] Figure 8. Prevention alert for execution of web shell loader component.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 000 800 050 45107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nSHA256 hash for IIServerCore\r\n\r\n \t(ServerCore.dll)\r\n \teeed5530fa1cdeb69398dc058aaa01160eab15d4dcdcd6cb841240987db284dc\r\n\r\nSHA256 hash for AssemblyExecuter V1\r\n\r\n \t(ExecuteAssembly.dll)\r\n \t3e55bf8ecaeec65871e6fca4cb2d4ff2586f83a20c12977858348492d2d0dec4\r\n\r\nSHA256 hash for AssemblyExecuter V2\r\n\r\n \t(ExecuteAssembly.dll)\r\n \tafcb6289a4ef48bf23bab16c0266f765fab8353d5e1b673bd6e39b315f83676e\r\n \tb76e243cf1886bd0e2357cbc7e1d2812c2c0ecc5068e61d681e0d5cff5b8e038\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tUNMASKED: Inside a New Chinese Nexus APT \u2013 Webinar, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tOperation Diplomatic Specter: An Active Chinese Cyberespionage Campaign Leverages Rare Tool Set to Target Governmental Entities in the Middle East, Africa and Asia \u2013 Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \tThrough the Cortex XDR Lens: Uncovering a New Activity Group Targeting Governments in the Middle East and Africa \u2013 Palo Alto Networks Blog\r\n \tNew Tool Set Found Used Against Organizations in the Middle East, Africa and the US \u2013 Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n\r\nAppendix A \u2013 Phantom Taurus Main TTPs\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTools\r\nMalware\r\nTechniques\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tHtran\r\n \tYasso\r\n \tJuicyPotatoNG\r\n \tNbtscan\r\n \tScansql\r\n \tLadon\r\n \tSamba SMBClient\r\n \tImpacket\r\n \tSharpEfsPotato\r\n \tiislpe\r\n \tMimikatz\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tTunnelSpecter\r\n \tSweetSpecter\r\n \tAgent Racoon\r\n \tIIServerCore\r\n \tAssemblyExecuter\r\n \tNtospy\r\n \tPlugX\r\n \tGh0st RAT\r\n \tChina Chopper\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tRunning an in-memory Visual Basic script implant to act as a web shell\r\n \tStealing credentials by misusing the network providers\r\n \tStealing emails by misusing the Exchange Management Shell entity\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Phantom Taurus main TTPs.\r\nAppendix B \u2013 IIServerCore Methods\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMethod Name\r\nDescription\r\n\r\n\r\nEncryptBase64\r\nReceives a plain text string and performs basic Base64 encoding (not encryption, despite the name). This function is used throughout the malware to obfuscate data transmission.\r\n\r\n\r\nDecryptBase64\r\nReceives a Base64-encoded string and decodes it back to plain text.\r\n\r\n\r\nEncrypt\r\nReceives raw byte data and an encryption key string. This function then performs AES encryption using ECB mode with PKCS7 padding. It creates an AES cipher with the provided key, encrypts the input data, and returns the encrypted bytes. The malware uses this method to secure communication with the C2.\r\n\r\n\r\nDecrypt\r\nReceives encrypted byte data and the corresponding key. The function then decrypts the data using AES decryption with the same ECB mode and PKCS7 padding settings. It reverses the encryption process to recover the original data, enabling the malware to process encrypted commands from the attacker.\r\n\r\n\r\nCompress\r\nReceives byte array data and compresses it using Gzip. Creates a compressed version of the input data to reduce the size of data it transmits between the malware and its C2 server, making network traffic less conspicuous.\r\n\r\n\r\nDecompress\r\nReceives Gzip-compressed byte data and decompresses it back to its original form.\r\n\r\n\r\nGetContext\r\nReceives a string containing the full request data. This function then extracts the payload portion and returns only the Base64-encoded payload data that contains the actual malicious payload.\r\n\r\n\r\nConvertToSpecialString\r\nTakes a list of dictionaries, each containing string key-value pairs, and converts them into a custom-formatted string. This string is used by the SetContext function to prepare command execution results.\r\n\r\n\r\nSetContext\r\nTakes the structured output from ConvertToSpecialString and applies multi-layer encoding (compression, encryption and Base64) that is later used for secure transmission back to the C2 server.\r\n\r\n\r\nGetMd5Hash\r\nReceives a string input and computes its MD5 hash.\r\n\r\n\r\nRun\r\nThe main execution function that receives the HTTP context and handles all malware operations.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. List of IIServerCore\u2019s methods.\r\nAppendix C \u2013 Built-In Commands\r\nThe following commands are embedded in the IIServerCore backdoor:\r\n\r\n \tfileExist\r\n \tlistDir\r\n \tcreateDir\r\n \trenameDir\r\n \tfileRead\r\n \tdeleteFile\r\n \tDictionary\r\n \tcreateFile\r\n \tchangeLastModified\r\n \tcode_self\r\n \tcode_pid\r\n \trun_code\r\n \taddshell\r\n \tbypassPrecompiledApp\r\n \tlistShell\r\n \tremoveShell\r\n \texecuteSQLQuery\r\n \tExecuteNonQuery\r\n","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2025\/09\/09-6-Phantom-Taurus-1920x900-1-300x300.png","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Lior Rochberger"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<link rel='stylesheet' id='post-views-counter-frontend-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/post-views-counter/css/frontend.min.css?ver=1.5.5' media='all' />
<style id='classic-theme-styles-inline-css'>

</style>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    </head>
<body class="wp-singular post-template-default single single-post postid-158604 single-format-standard wp-theme-unit42-v6 no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

</ul>  </div>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>

<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/09-6-Phantom-Taurus-1920x900-1.png')">

          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:Lior Rochberger" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/lior-rochberger/">Lior Rochberger</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>September 30, 2025</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:Malware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/">Malware</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:Threat Actor Groups" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/">Threat Actor Groups</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:China" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/china/">China</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:CL-STA-0043" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cl-sta-0043/">CL-STA-0043</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:Phantom Taurus" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phantom-taurus/">Phantom Taurus</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:TGR-STA-0043" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/tgr-sta-0043/">TGR-STA-0043</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phantom-taurus/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=52d9068c24" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantom-taurus:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-158604-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Phantom Taurus is a previously undocumented nation-state actor whose espionage operations align with People’s Republic of China (PRC) state interests. Over the past two and a half years, Unit 42 researchers have observed Phantom Taurus targeting government and telecommunications organizations across Africa, the Middle East, and Asia.</p>
<p>Our observations show that Phantom Taurus’ main focus areas include ministries of foreign affairs, embassies, geopolitical events and military operations. The group’s primary objective is espionage. Its attacks demonstrate stealth, persistence and an ability to quickly adapt their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs).</p>
<p>What sets Phantom Taurus apart from other actors in the Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) nexus is its distinctive set of TTPs. These enable the group to conduct highly covert operations and maintain long-term access to critical targets. This article sheds more light on the threat actor’s recently observed TTPs and reveals a previously undocumented custom tool in Phantom Taurus’ arsenal called NET-STAR.</p>
<p>We <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/security-operations/through-the-cortex-xdr-lens-uncovering-a-new-activity-group-targeting-governments-in-the-middle-east-and-africa/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">published our first article</a> about this activity cluster (originally tracked as CL-STA-0043) in June 2023. In May 2024, we promoted the classification of this cluster to a temporary group, which we designated <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/operation-diplomatic-specter/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">TGR-STA-0043</a> and nicknamed Operation Diplomatic Specter. Our ongoing investigations into this group deepened our understanding of the threat actor’s operations and enabled us to determine its connection to the Chinese nexus. This rare level of insight reflects the depth and duration of our investigation.</p>
<p>After sustained observation and intelligence collection over the past year, we have accumulated sufficient evidence to classify the temporary group as a new threat actor. Our attribution and cluster maturation process is based on <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-attribution-framework" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42’s attribution framework</a>. Figure 1 shows the process of promoting Phantom Taurus from a cluster of activity to a formally named threat actor.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows the process of promoting Phantom Taurus from a cluster of activity to a formally named threat actor.</p>
<figure id="attachment_159755" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-159755" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-159755 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-scaled.png" alt="Timeline from 2022 to 2025 showing the evolution of a cybersecurity threat group. Starts with &quot;CLA-STA-0043 Activity Cluster&quot; in 2022, progresses to &quot;TGR-STA-0043 Temporary Group Name&quot; in 2024, and becomes &quot;Phantom Taurus, New Formally-Named Threat Actor&quot; by 2025. Includes logos of Palo Alto Networks and Unit 42." width="1000" height="409" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-scaled.png 2560w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-786x322.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-1710x700.png 1710w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-768x314.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-1536x629.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/2601-Phantom-Taurus-Figure-1-Phantom-Taurus-Maturation-2048x838.png 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-159755" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. The maturation process of Phantom Taurus.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Threat Actor Groups</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/tgr-sta-0043/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">TGR-STA-0043</a></strong>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cl-sta-0043/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">CL-STA-0043</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-158604-_tx8tdak2vr9s"></a>Phantom Taurus: The Evolution of a Threat Actor</h2>
<p>Phantom Taurus is a Chinese APT group that conducts long-term intelligence collection operations against high-value targets to obtain sensitive, non-public information.</p>
<p>The group primarily targets government entities and government service providers across the Middle East, Africa and Asia. The targeting patterns align consistently with the People's Republic of China (PRC) economic and geopolitical interests. We observed that the group takes an interest in diplomatic communications, defense-related intelligence and the operations of critical governmental ministries. The timing and scope of the group’s operations frequently coincide with major global events and regional security affairs.</p>
<p>Our technical analysis reveals that the group employs a unique set of custom-developed tools and implements techniques that are rarely observed in the threat landscape. The list of TTPs is provided in <a href="#post-158604-_7mib773okdxz">Appendix A</a>.</p>
<p>This group's distinctive modus operandi, combined with its advanced operational practices, sets Phantom Taurus apart from other Chinese APT groups. The designation of this group as a distinct Chinese APT is supported by multiple attribution factors, as illustrated in the <a href="https://www.threatintel.academy/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/diamond_summary.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Diamond Model of attribution [PDF]</a> shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158627" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158627" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158627 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2.png" alt="Diamond model framework for Phantom Taurus. Sections include Capabilities including various malware and tools like Ghost RAT and Yama. Infrastructure similarities to other groups, and Victimology including entities in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. " width="1000" height="833" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2-528x440.png 528w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2-840x700.png 840w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2-768x640.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-123879-158604-2-1536x1280.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158627" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Diamond Model representation of Phantom Taurus.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-158604-_2zcamsh44nnj"></a>Diamond Model Attribution Breakdown</h3>
<p><a id="post-158604-_472arcsd3qhb"></a>We established the attribution of Phantom Taurus through a comprehensive analysis of the following Diamond Model elements:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Infrastructure:</strong> Phantom Taurus uses a shared Chinese APT operational infrastructure that has been exclusively used by Chinese threat actors, including Iron Taurus (aka <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/apt27/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">APT27</a>), <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/starchy-taurus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Starchy Taurus</a> (aka <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/Winnti/">Winnti</a>) and <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/stately-taurus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Stately Taurus</a> (aka <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mustang-panda/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Mustang Panda</a>). However, the specific infrastructure components used by Phantom Taurus have not been observed in operations by other threat actors, indicating operational compartmentalization within this shared ecosystem.</li>
<li><strong>Victimology:</strong> The group consistently targets high-value organizations that have access to sensitive non-public information. Over the past several years, we have observed Phantom Taurus targeting government and telecommunications sector organizations, particularly those that provide services and infrastructure. This group focuses its operations on the Middle East, Africa and Asia, reflecting intelligence collection priorities that align with Chinese strategic interests.</li>
<li><strong>Capabilities:</strong> Phantom Taurus employs a set of TTPs that differentiate it from other threat actors. Several of these techniques have not been observed in operations by other groups, while others are sufficiently rare that only a handful of actors have been observed using similar methods. In addition to common tools such as China Chopper, the Potato suite and Impacket, the group uses customized tools, including the Specter malware family, Ntospy and the NET-STAR malware suite described <a href="#post-158604-_vptyl672sdmq">later in this article</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>By using the Diamond Model of attribution with the three nodes shown in Figure 2, we mapped the group’s similarities and overlaps with other threat actors. As we tracked the activity for an extended period, it became clear that the activities that we observed were carried out by a new threat actor.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158604-_stiyfxap5nfc"></a>Charting the Course From Email to Databases: Phantom Taurus’ New Data Collection Methods</h3>
<p>Our continuous monitoring of Phantom Taurus activities has revealed a tactical evolution that we first observed in early 2025. Since 2023, Phantom Taurus has focused on stealing sensitive and specific emails of interest from email servers, as we described in a <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/operation-diplomatic-specter/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previous article</a>. However, our telemetry indicates a shift from this email-centric methodology to the direct targeting of databases.</p>
<p>We observed Phantom Taurus using a script named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mssq.bat</span> to connect to and collect data from a targeted database.</p>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mssq.bat</span> script operates in the following manner:</p>
<ul>
<li>Connects to an SQL Server database with a given server name, a user ID named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sa</span> (system administrator) and a password that the attackers previously obtained</li>
<li>Reads the SQL query provided in the command-line arguments by the group’s operators. This allows dynamic searching for tables and specific keywords</li>
<li>Executes the provided query and returns the results that match the user’s search</li>
<li>Exports results to a CSV file</li>
<li>Closes the database connection</li>
</ul>
<p>The threat actor leveraged Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mssq.bat</span> script on the remote SQL Server. Figure 3 shows that the command contains both the embedded script and the execution instructions.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158638" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158638" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158638 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-128088-158604-3.png" alt="Screenshot of diagram in Cortex XDR. There are three circular interface icons depicting network connections below the error messages. Some of the text is highlighting to show the BAT file execution. " width="1000" height="328" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-128088-158604-3.png 1370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-128088-158604-3-786x258.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-128088-158604-3-768x252.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158638" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Execution of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mssq.bat</span> as shown in Cortex XDR.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The threat actor used this method to search for documents of interest and information related to specific countries such as Afghanistan and Pakistan.</p>
<h2><a id="post-158604-_vptyl672sdmq"></a>The New NET-STAR Malware Suite</h2>
<p>In addition to Phantom Taurus’ shift to collecting data from databases, we observed the group using a new and undocumented malware suite in its recent operations. This new tool is a .NET malware suite designed to target Internet Information Services (IIS) web servers. We named the suite NET-STAR, based on the use of the string in the malware’s program database (PDB) paths:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop\tmp\<strong>NETstar</strong>shard\ServerCore\obj\Release\ServerCore.pdb</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Users\admin\Desktop\starshard\<strong>NETstar</strong>shard\ExecuteAssembly\obj\Debug\ExecuteAssembly.pdb</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">STAR</span> string also appears as a delimiter in Base64-encoded data. The NET-STAR malware suite demonstrates Phantom Taurus’ advanced evasion techniques and a deep understanding of .NET architecture, representing a significant threat to internet-facing servers. The suite consists of three distinct web-based backdoors, each serving a specific role in the attack chain while maintaining persistence within the target’s IIS environment:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>IIServerCore:</strong> A fileless modular backdoor that supports in-memory execution of command-line arguments, arbitrary commands and payloads</li>
<li><strong>AssemblyExecuter V1:</strong> Loads and executes additional .NET payloads in memory</li>
<li><strong>AssemblyExecuter V2:</strong> An enhanced version of AssemblyExecuter V1 that is also equipped with <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/amsi/antimalware-scan-interface-portal" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Antimalware Scan Interface</a> (AMSI) and <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/devtest/event-tracing-for-windows--etw-" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Event Tracing for Windows</a> (ETW) bypass capabilities</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-158604-_dsvonrj019uo"></a>IIServerCore: A Modular Fileless IIS Backdoor</h3>
<p>IIServerCore is the main web-based backdoor component in the NET-STAR malware suite. After being loaded by the web shell loader component, the backdoor operates entirely in memory within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">w3wp.exe</span> IIS worker process.</p>
<p>The IIServerCore backdoor has a unique modular, fileless execution flow that allows it to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Receive additional payloads and arguments</li>
<li>Execute them in memory</li>
<li>Send the results in an encrypted command and control (C2) communication channel</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 4 shows the execution flow.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158649" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158649" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158649 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-130953-158604-4.png" alt="Illustration of a web-based process. 1. Web shell receives HTTP request. 2. Web shell loads ServerRun class into memory. 3. ServerRun establishes encrypted session. 4. ServerRun loads third-stage payload based on commands. 5. ServerRun executes operations and returns encrypted results. 6. All artifacts remain in memory only." width="1000" height="298" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-130953-158604-4.png 1319w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-130953-158604-4-786x234.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-130953-158604-4-768x229.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158649" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. IIServerCore execution flow.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-158604-_ygf8e5xn32io"></a>IIServerCore Under the Hood: From Web Shell Loader to Fileless Malware</h4>
<p>The initial component of IIServerCore is an ASPX web shell named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OutlookEN.aspx</span>. This web shell contains an embedded Base64-compressed binary, the IIServerCore backdoor. When the web shell executes, it loads the backdoor into the memory of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">w3wp.exe</span> process and invokes the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> method, which is the main function of IIServerCore. Figure 5 shows the web shell.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158660" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158660" style="width: 1073px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158660 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-134174-158604-5.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer code in an IDE with certain lines highlighted in red, specifically focusing on system reflection methods and assembly loading. The text is set on a dark background. Syntax highlighting is applied. " width="1073" height="413" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-134174-158604-5.png 1073w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-134174-158604-5-786x303.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-134174-158604-5-768x296.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1073px) 100vw, 1073px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158660" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Web shell content of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OutlookEN.aspx</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In an attempt to evade detection efforts, the threat actor <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1070/006/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">timestomped</a> the ASPX file to match the timestamp of another old ASPX file found on the operating system. The threat actor timestomped not only the web shell, but also the backdoors in the NET-STAR malware suite. The actor changed the compilation time to a random future date to hide the malware’s real compilation timestamp.</p>
<p>IIServerCore also supports a command called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">changeLastModified</span>. This suggests that the malware has active timestomping capabilities, designed to confuse security analysts and digital forensics tools.</p>
<h4><a id="post-158604-_n9f3hcpq0ytp"></a>Breaking Down IIServerCore Method by Method</h4>
<p>The IIServerCore backdoor consists of a class called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ServerRun</span> and 11 methods. This includes a main method named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> as well as several others that provide additional capabilities. The methods and their descriptions are listed in <a href="#post-158604-_bihjs2wtozbu">Appendix B</a>.</p>
<p>The main method, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span>, receives the incoming communication and handles all malware operations. This method processes two types of requests:</p>
<ul>
<li>Initial handshake requests to establish a session with the C2 server</li>
<li>Subsequent command execution requests to load and execute .NET assemblies dynamically</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 6 shows the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> method.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158671" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158671" style="width: 791px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158671 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-137176-158604-6.png" alt="Image of a computer screen displaying software code, featuring functions for extracting session data and parsing STAR-delimited parameters along with a list of built-in commands in the editor. Annotated arrows and text highlight specific sections of the code." width="791" height="1099" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-137176-158604-6.png 791w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-137176-158604-6-317x440.png 317w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-137176-158604-6-504x700.png 504w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-137176-158604-6-768x1067.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 791px) 100vw, 791px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158671" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Screenshot of IIServerCore main method Run.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> method manages the session state using cookies. This behavior allows the method to track and maintain information about a user’s session across multiple web requests. It decrypts incoming commands and payloads, loads .NET code from Base64-encoded assemblies and supports data encryption.</p>
<p>The backdoor supports various built-in commands that provide a wide range of functionalities, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>File system operations</li>
<li>Database access, including running SQL commands</li>
<li>Arbitrary code execution</li>
<li>Web shell management to deploy and manage multiple web shells</li>
<li>Antivirus evasion: AMSI bypass functionality</li>
<li>Encrypted C2 communication, where all communications are AES encrypted</li>
<li>Memory-only execution: payloads are loaded directly into memory</li>
</ul>
<p>The full list of commands is provided in <a href="#post-158604-_km3ks9gajcvn">Appendix C</a>.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158604-_3srowjxup9ch"></a>Two New Variants of .NET Malware Loaders</h3>
<p>The second component in the NET-STAR suite is another .NET IIS malware that we named AssemblyExecuter. During our investigation, we observed two versions of AssemblyExecuter:</p>
<ul>
<li>An older version (v1) that we believe the threat actors initially used around 2024</li>
<li>A newer version (v2) that we believe they used in 2025</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-158604-_qrtowz1r9ksr"></a>AssemblyExecuter V1</h4>
<p>The first AssemblyExecuter version is a .NET assembly designed for a single, specific purpose of executing other .NET assemblies directly in memory without writing them to disk.</p>
<p>This component enables threat actors to dynamically load and execute additional functionality after a compromise. The backdoor accepts assembly bytecode as input parameters, loads it using the .NET<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> Assembly.Load()</span> method and invokes the assembly’s entry point along with specified command-line arguments.</p>
<p>The component’s seemingly benign code structure results in <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/3e55bf8ecaeec65871e6fca4cb2d4ff2586f83a20c12977858348492d2d0dec4" target="_blank" rel="noopener">minimal flagging by antivirus engines</a> on VirusTotal, at the time of writing this article. This demonstrates a technique that threat actors can use to create tools that avoid overt code, which detection systems might interpret as malicious.</p>
<h4><a id="post-158604-_rzwjipyxmoig"></a>AssemblyExecuter V2</h4>
<p>The second AssemblyExecuter version maintains the same core purpose as its predecessor, executing arbitrary .NET assemblies directly in memory. This version has enhanced evasion capabilities to operate in more heavily monitored environments.</p>
<p>While the fundamental assembly loading and execution logic remain unchanged, AssemblyExecuter v2 includes dedicated methods for bypassing two critical Windows security mechanisms, AMSI and ETW. The malware dynamically determines which bypass techniques to apply based on input parameters, allowing attackers to selectively disable security controls, depending on the target environment’s configuration.</p>
<p>Figure 7 displays the input parameters that the attackers used to achieve bypass.</p>
<figure id="attachment_158682" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158682" style="width: 768px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158682 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-140348-158604-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer code snippet in that involves string manipulation and error handling. A portion is highlighted in a yellow box." width="768" height="850" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-140348-158604-7.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-140348-158604-7-398x440.png 398w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-140348-158604-7-632x700.png 632w" sizes="(max-width: 768px) 100vw, 768px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158682" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Security bypass code inside AssemblyExecuter V2.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-158604-_2285fsw6bleq"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This article details the maturation of activity cluster CL-STA-0043 to a formally designated threat actor, Phantom Taurus. We also provide a detailed technical analysis of NET-STAR, a previously undiscovered malware suite that represents a significant evolution in this actor's operational capabilities.</p>
<p>The extensive evidence that we gathered provides crucial insights into adversary persistence, adaptability, evolution process and strategic intent that short-term analysis cannot always capture.</p>
<p>The formal designation of Phantom Taurus demonstrates the value of sustained threat actor tracking. Our multi-year investigation exemplifies how long-term monitoring enables a comprehensive understanding of threat actor evolution and operational capabilities.</p>
<h3><a id="post-158604-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> has an inbuilt machine learning-based detection that can detect exploits in real time.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a>.
<ul>
<li>The XDR agent is designed to protect against the initial NET-STAR malware loader, preventing the execution of the attack chain outlined in this article.</li>
<li>Figure 8 shows that the execution of the loader component was detected and prevented by the web shell protection module.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_158693" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-158693" style="width: 970px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-158693 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-143240-158604-8.png" alt="Image displaying a security alert log in Cortex XDR with columns labeled: Severity, which shows 'High' with a red indicator; Alert Source, labeled as 'XDR Agent'; Action, indicating 'Prevented (Blocked)'; Alert Name; Description, described as 'Web shell execution'; and Initiated by, marked as an EXE file." width="970" height="122" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-143240-158604-8.png 970w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-143240-158604-8-786x99.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/word-image-143240-158604-8-768x97.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 970px) 100vw, 970px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-158693" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Prevention alert for execution of web shell loader component.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 000 800 050 45107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-158604-_v8176g40kstn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">SHA256 hash for IIServerCore</span></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">(</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">ServerCore.dll</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">)</span></span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">eeed5530fa1cdeb69398dc058aaa01160eab15d4dcdcd6cb841240987db284dc</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SHA256 hash for AssemblyExecuter V1</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(ExecuteAssembly.dll)</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3e55bf8ecaeec65871e6fca4cb2d4ff2586f83a20c12977858348492d2d0dec4</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SHA256 hash for AssemblyExecuter V2</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">(ExecuteAssembly.dll)</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">afcb6289a4ef48bf23bab16c0266f765fab8353d5e1b673bd6e39b315f83676e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b76e243cf1886bd0e2357cbc7e1d2812c2c0ecc5068e61d681e0d5cff5b8e038</span></li>
</ul>

<h2><a id="post-158604-_7mib773okdxz"></a>Appendix A – Phantom Taurus Main TTPs</h2>

<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Malware</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Techniques</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Htran</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yasso</span></li>

<td>

<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TunnelSpecter</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SweetSpecter</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Agent Racoon</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">IIServerCore</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">AssemblyExecuter</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ntospy</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PlugX</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gh0st RAT</span></li>
